TF-IDF Processing

This module provides Term Frequency-Inverse Document Frequency (TF-IDF) calculation functions for both Turkish and English text processing.

Main TF-IDF Interface

TF-IDF (Term Frequency-Inverse Document Frequency) Package

This package provides functionality for calculating TF-IDF matrices from document collections. Supports both English and Turkish text processing with various TF-IDF weighting schemes.

functions.tfidf.tfidf_hesapla(N=None, sozluk=None, data=None, output_dir=None, alanadi=None, lemmatize=False)[source]

Calculates Term Frequency-Inverse Document Frequency (TF-IDF) matrix from document collection.

This function processes a collection of documents to create a TF-IDF sparse matrix representation. It uses chunked processing to handle large datasets efficiently and provides memory usage statistics. The function supports optional lemmatization during text preprocessing and calculates optimal topic modeling parameters based on the resulting matrix sparsity.

Parameters:

  • N (int, optional) – Total number of documents in the dataset. Used for matrix dimension sizing.

  • sozluk (list, optional) – Sorted vocabulary list where each word corresponds to a matrix column index. The vocabulary should be pre-sorted for efficient binary search operations.

  • data (pandas.DataFrame or dict, optional) – Document collection containing the text data to process. Should have a column/key specified by alanadi parameter.

  • output_dir (str, optional) – Directory path for saving output files. Currently unused in implementation.

  • alanadi (str, optional) – Field/column name in data containing the document texts to process.

  • lemmatize (bool, optional) – Whether to apply lemmatization during text preprocessing. Default is False. When True, reduces words to their base forms for better semantic grouping.

Returns:

Sparse TF-IDF matrix with shape (N, len(sozluk)) where:

  • Rows represent documents

  • Columns represent vocabulary terms

  • Values are TF-IDF scores

  • Matrix uses LIL (List of Lists) format for efficient incremental construction

Return type:

scipy.sparse.lil_matrix

Side Effects:

  • Prints lemmatization status at function start

  • Prints detailed memory usage statistics including: * Required memory for dense matrix representation * Actual memory usage of sparse matrix * Count of non-zero elements * Optimal topic count estimation * Sparsity percentage

  • Updates progress via Redis bridge (currently commented out)

  • May raise and re-propagate exceptions with progress updates

functions.tfidf.tf_idf_generator(veri, tokenizer)[source]

This function generates a TF-IDF matrix for a given list of text data. 1) Convert the text data to a sparse matrix. 2) Calculate the TF-IDF score for the sparse matrix. 3) Return the TF-IDF matrix.

Parameters:

  • veri (list) – A list of text data.

  • tokenizer (Tokenizer) – A trained tokenizer.

Returns:

A sparse TF-IDF matrix.

Return type:

csr_matrix

functions.tfidf.tf_b(x)[source]

Apply binary term frequency weighting (presence/absence of terms).

Parameters:

x (csr_matrix) – Sparse matrix containing term frequencies

Returns:

Binary term frequency matrix where all non-zero values become 1

Return type:

csr_matrix

functions.tfidf.tf_d(x)[source]

Apply double logarithm term frequency weighting using 1 + log2(1 + log2(tf)).

Parameters:

x (csr_matrix) – Sparse matrix containing term frequencies

Returns:

Double logarithm weighted term frequency matrix

Return type:

csr_matrix

Logarithm weighted term frequency matrix

Return type:

functions.tfidf.tf_L(x)[source]

Apply length-normalized logarithm term frequency weighting.

Uses (1 + log2(tf)) / (1 + log2(avg_tf_per_doc)) for normalization.

Parameters:

x (csr_matrix) – Sparse matrix containing term frequencies

Returns:

Length-normalized logarithm weighted term frequency matrix

Return type:

csr_matrix

functions.tfidf.idf_t(df, dokuman_sayisi)[source]

Calculate smoothed IDF scores using log2((1+N)/df).

Parameters:

  • df (np.ndarray) – Document frequency array

  • dokuman_sayisi (int) – Total number of documents

Returns:

Smoothed IDF scores (avoids division by zero)

Return type:

np.ndarray

functions.tfidf.idf_p(df, dokuman_sayisi)[source]

Calculate probabilistic IDF scores using log2((N-df+1)/(df+1)).

Parameters:

  • df (np.ndarray) – Document frequency array

  • dokuman_sayisi (int) – Total number of documents

Returns:

Probabilistic IDF scores

Return type:

np.ndarray

  • dokuman_sayisi (int) – Total number of documents
